issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

fields.summary: Eucalyptus DNS causes issues with S3 Tools (e.g s3cmd)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
At times when trying to access the EPC on epc.eucalyptus.com which is a CNAME for eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com (the CLC of that cloud) the first try fails. It happens from time to time but on the second request the DNS seems to answer and the connection occurs.

I currently don't have logs to give you but if I see it happen again then I will try to post some. I have looked in the past but have not seen anything jump at me as a possible error in the logs that is related.

comments.body:
Comment from gholms:

This can also happen when pointing s3cmd at walrus.
Waiting for logs from [~hspencer]

Cloud logs attached after folks did DNS lookups for eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com.  Ran host against eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com and got the following:

{code}
$ host  eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com
eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
Host eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
Host eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
{code}
Nothing interesting in the logs except a _lot_ of exceptions about one particular access key.  I doubt that's related.

A note on the output of the "host" command.  I checked tcpdump, and the failures you are seeing there are failures to look up AAAA and MX records, which I assume that the eucalyptus DNS server does not set.  So that would be expected behavior, and unrelated the the problem [~ahamilton] is seeing.

I guess that I should clarify that it does happen when using the A record of the cloud at eucalyptus.partner.eucalyptus.com and is not just an issue with the CNAME. Sorry if there might have been some confusion there.
Looks like the logs have been provided.  What is the next step on this issue?

This is biting us on ECC today, right now.  A full log of the IRC discussion follows, with my own DNS ignorance included for your edification.

10:44:25 < gregdek> bteachenor: having any problems with DNS for ECC?
10:44:55 < gregdek> Greg-DeKoenigsbergs-MacBook:~ gregdek$ host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com
10:44:55 < gregdek> ;; connection timed out; no servers could be reached
10:45:01 < bteachenor> Other than the known bug?
10:47:16 < bteachenor> https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-4396
10:51:59 -!- Up2 [~Up2@198.228.207.244] has quit [Quit: Colloquy for iPad - http://colloquy.mobi]
10:54:27 < gregdek> Oh!
10:54:28  * gregdek looks.
10:55:07 < gregdek> I was unaware.
10:55:53 < bteachenor> Basically, DNS resolution on the Eucalyptus end seems unreliable, and your DNS server will probably cache the NX result for 
                       a while... :-(
10:56:08 < gregdek> Piffle.
10:58:14 < gregdek> So this means that anyone trying to use the ECC right now, whose DNS server has updated since the Euca DNS server went 
                    sleepybyes, is unable to use it?
11:07:12 -!- scotm [~scotm@67.189.56.13] has quit [Remote host closed the connection]
11:09:55 -!- rprasanna [~rpv2892@180.215.56.222] has quit [Ping timeout: 248 seconds]
11:10:17 < gregdek> bteachenor: am I understanding right? ^^^
11:14:15 < cpt_yesterday> gregdek: no
11:14:26 < gregdek> Good. :)
11:14:54 < cpt_yesterday> It's only intermittent so usually if you get a reply back with nothing if you try again it should give you info
11:14:54 < gregdek> Are these transient failures, then, and whoever caches the busted record in the wrong window is screwed for a while?
11:15:23 < cpt_yesterday> If it doesn't get a reply then it won't cache anything
11:15:31 < cpt_yesterday> s/reply/answer/
11:16:44  * gregdek struggles with his own dumbness.
11:16:52 < gregdek> So when I run the following command:
11:17:03 < gregdek> host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com
11:17:08 < gregdek> And repeatedly get:
11:17:13 < gregdek> ;; connection timed out; no servers could be reached
11:17:45 < gregdek> ...isn't that happening at the DNS level of the ISP, and mustn't it be cached there?
11:17:53 < gregdek> Sorry if this is Internet 101 stuff... :/
11:18:40 < cpt_yesterday> Still only if it gets an address
11:20:03 < noirin> cpt_yesterday: But if it doesn't get an address, it should be trying again, no? In which case gregdek should get 173.205.188.7 
                   or something?
11:20:04 < bteachenor> gregdek: What do you get with 'host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com 173.205.188.7'
11:20:05 < bteachenor> ?
11:20:38  * gregdek looks.
11:20:38  * gregdek looks.
11:20:52 < gregdek> Happiness.
11:20:58 < gregdek> eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
11:22:27 < cpt_yesterday> noirin: Yes the DNS server should try a couple times to try to get an address until it reaches its max
11:23:33 < noirin> So if he's getting repeated connection timed out, it's maybe because it's already reached max?
11:23:50 < cpt_yesterday> Yeah
11:24:07 < noirin> Aha, that makes sense
11:24:09 < noirin> Thanks :-)
11:25:45 < gregdek> OK. Ping got stuck for about 3 mins and then broke through. 
11:26:31 < gregdek> I'm guessing the host command doesn't force a retry.
11:27:09 < gregdek> ...
11:29:16 < gregdek> OK, so then I ran host again and got this:
11:29:23 < gregdek> host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com
11:29:23 < gregdek> eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
11:29:23 < gregdek> ;; connection timed out; no servers could be reached
11:29:23 < gregdek> ;; connection timed out; no servers could be reached
11:29:30 < gregdek> And then ping subsequently times out:
11:29:37 < gregdek> ping eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com
11:29:39 < gregdek> ping: cannot resolve eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com: Unknown host
11:29:49 < gregdek> I dunno if this is helpful to anyone.
11:30:15 < bteachenor> gregdek:  what nameservers does your /etc/resolv.conf have?
11:30:39 < gregdek> domain nc.rr.com
11:30:40 < gregdek> nameserver 10.0.1.1
11:30:58 < noirin> gregdek: Weirdly, I get the same for host on an ubuntu machine, but different on OSX
11:31:20 < noirin> (OSX just returns the one successful line)
11:31:47 < gregdek> Which I suppose is the local wireless here bridging out to time warner's dns.
11:31:50 < noirin> My ubuntu resolv.conf has nameserver 80.68.80.24
11:31:51 < noirin> nameserver 80.68.80.25
11:32:14 < gregdek> noirin: and your ubuntu machine fails dns lookup?
11:32:24 < bteachenor> gregdek: Can you temporarily modify the nameserver to be 8.8.8.8 to see if Google's nameserver will give you different 
                       results from your ISP?
11:32:35 < gregdek> Yep, one sec.
11:32:48 < noirin> gregdek: Nope, it successfully looks up
11:32:50 < noirin> But it returns eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
11:32:53 < noirin> Host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com not found: 2(SERVFAIL)
11:32:56 < noirin> Host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com not found: 2(SERVFAIL)
11:33:09 < noirin> (Successfully in the sense of, y'know, it finds the IP and can ping it :-))
11:33:47 -!- Irssi: Pasting 8 lines to #eucalyptus-meeting. Press Ctrl-K if you wish to do this or Ctrl-C to cancel.
11:33:54 < gregdek> OK, so I run:
11:34:03 < gregdek> host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com 8.8.8.8
11:34:05 < gregdek> And I get:
11:34:16 < gregdek> eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
11:34:16 < gregdek> Host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
11:34:17 < gregdek> Host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
11:34:30 < bteachenor> OK.  That's what you're supposed to get.
11:34:40 < bteachenor> From the man page for host: "By default, it looks for A, AAAA, and MX records"
11:35:01 < bteachenor> Eucalyptus doesn't serve any AAAA or MX records for the 2nd and 3rd queries.
11:35:10 < bteachenor> But the A record is there.
11:35:30 < gregdek> Ah, ok.
11:35:53 < gregdek> ping still fails, though.
11:36:00 < noirin> bteachenor: How come the SERVFAIL though?
11:36:01 < gregdek> (Maybe it should, I dunno.)
11:36:13 < noirin> Is that just a server returning something bogus when it really means NXDOMAIN?
11:36:29 < bteachenor> I think that your ISP cached a negative (non-existant) result for eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com and will need to wait until 
                       the Minimum Cache Time expires for the ecc.eucalyptus.com zone (I don't know what that value is.)
11:36:59 < noirin> I get the SERVFAIL using 8.8.8.8
11:37:31 < bteachenor> noirin: I believe it's a valid response.  Since we don't do IPv6, and there isn't a mail exchanger for ecc.eucalyptus.com, 
                       there shouldn't be AAAA and MX records, and it SHOULD return NXDOMAIN responses.
11:37:50 < gregdek> But not SERVFAIL?
11:37:57 < bteachenor> Ask a Euca developer.
11:38:02 < gregdek> :)
11:38:29 < noirin> :-)
11:39:25 < gregdek> "SERVFAIL means that the domain does exist and the root name servers have information on this domain, but that the 
                    authoritative name servers are not answering queries for this domain."
11:39:39 < gregdek> Well, anyway.
11:40:32 < bteachenor> OK.  And the Eucalyptus DNS service is authoritative for the ecc.eucalyptus.com zone...
11:41:01 < bteachenor> So it appears that there are still some issues with the DNS service in Eucalyptus.

So, when I try to slam the Eucalyptus DNS server directly I do not get any errors.  I let the following loop run for several thousand iterations.

{code}
a=0;while ! host eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com 173.205.188.7  | grep NXDOMAIN; do sleep .1;echo "TRIAL $((a++))";done
{code}


Looks like there is badness w/ NS records for ecc.eucalyptus.com because 173.205.188.7 has a PTR entry for partner-cloud.eucalyptus.com which doesn't have an A record.
{code}
# 
 ~   10133 > host -t ns ecc.eucalyptus.com 
ecc.eucalyptus.com name server 173.205.188.7.

 ~   10133 > host -t ptr 173.205.188.7
7.188.205.173.in-addr.arpa domain name pointer partner-frontend.eucalyptus.com.

 ~   10133 > host -t a partner-frontend.eucalyptus.com
Host partner-frontend.eucalyptus.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
{code}

I hadn't updated the PTR record for the changeover/upgrade from EPC to ECC.  That's done now.  Thanks for noticing Chris!

It may be that this happens when the system is under heavy load, and for some reason not able to respond to the DNS request within the two second timeout?

[~bteachenor] What I ran the loop above some of the requests took as long as 5 seconds every now and then, but those were still successful resolutions.  Where does the 2 second timeout you mentioned come from?  Do you think there is there a systematic way of reproducing the issue?

{code}
TRIAL 33
Name: 173.205.188.7
Address: 173.205.188.7#53
eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7
eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com has address 173.205.188.7

real	0m5.241s
user	0m0.004s
sys	0m0.008s
{code}

The issue isn't when the DNS is getting hammered. The issue begins to manifest itself when the cloud has been able to sit for a while. It seems that if there isn't any access to the cloud for some amount of time, that time I do not know, the first request will fail. After that, future requests will succeed without issue.

The issue occurred tonight when I tried to SSH from my desktop to communitycloud.eucalyptus.com (a CNAME to eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com) and the first connection failed due to a look up. The next SSH connection succeeded without issue.
[~decker], if you need help reproducing this, let me know.  I see it often when using euca2ools against ECC, in the form of a [gaierror|http://docs.python.org/2/library/socket.html#socket.gaierror].

[~agrimm] Yes, please.  Could you try doing: {{dig   eucalyptus.ecc.eucalyptus.com A +trace}}

Any guidance on reproduction would enable pursuing the issue.
[~hspencer], can you please put in the steps to reproduce, including the logfiles.   [~decker] will followup in the ticket with some additional detail.

Regarding my setup - it as follows:

HA Cloud is setup in 6755 office with DNS information configured in primary DNS server in the office.  The following steps were followed:

{code}
(page 79-80)

######

zone "yourdomain" { type master; file "/etc/bind/db.yourdomain"; };
#Forward
eucadomain.yourdomain zone "eucadomain.yourdomain" { type forward;
forward
only; forwarders { <CLC_0_IP>; <CLC_1_IP>; }; };

## /etc/bind/db.<whatever domain>

$TTL 604800 @ IN SOA yourdomain. root.yourdomain. ( 2 ; Serial 604800
; Refresh

86400 ; Retry 2419200 ; Expire 604800 ) ; Negative Cache TTL ; @ IN NS
ns.yourdomain. @ IN A <master_nameserver_IP> ns.yourdomain. IN A
<master_nameserver_IP> ;Add entries for primary and secondary CLCs
eucadomain.yourdomain. IN NS clc0.eucadomain.yourdomain.
eucadomain.yourdomain.
IN NS clc1.eucadomain.yourdomain. clc0.eucadomain.yourdomain. IN A
<CLC_0_IP>
clc1.eucadomain.yourdomain. IN A <CLC_1_IP>
{code}

Services listed are as follows:

{code}
# euca-describe-services
SERVICE	cluster        	enter-the-wu   	gza            	DISABLED  	20  	http://192.168.39.104:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:enter-the-wu:cluster:gza/
SERVICE	cluster        	enter-the-wu   	rza            	ENABLED   	20  	http://192.168.39.103:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:enter-the-wu:cluster:rza/
SERVICE	bootstrap      	bootstrap      	192.168.39.101 	ENABLED   	20  	http://192.168.39.101:8773/services/Empyrean	arn:euca:bootstrap:::192.168.39.101/
SERVICE	storage        	enter-the-wu   	method-man     	ENABLED   	20  	http://192.168.39.103:8773/services/Storage	arn:euca:eucalyptus:enter-the-wu:storage:method-man/
SERVICE	eucalyptus     	eucalyptus     	192.168.39.101 	ENABLED   	20  	http://192.168.39.101:8773/services/Eucalyptus	arn:euca:eucalyptus:::192.168.39.101/
SERVICE	eucalyptus     	eucalyptus     	192.168.39.102 	DISABLED  	20  	http://192.168.39.102:8773/services/Eucalyptus	arn:euca:eucalyptus:::192.168.39.102/
SERVICE	walrus         	walrus         	iron-flag      	ENABLED   	20  	http://192.168.39.102:8773/services/Walrus	arn:euca:bootstrap:walrus:walrus:iron-flag/
SERVICE	walrus         	walrus         	wu-tang-forever	DISABLED  	20  	http://192.168.39.101:8773/services/Walrus	arn:euca:bootstrap:walrus:walrus:wu-tang-forever/
SERVICE	dns            	eucalyptus     	192.168.39.101 	ENABLED   	20  	http://192.168.39.101:8773/services/Dns 	arn:euca:eucalyptus::dns:192.168.39.101/
{code}

From my laptop on VPN, I get the following behavior when I do lookups:

{code}
euca-prod-1-82:s3cmd haroldspencerjr$ host walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com has address 192.168.39.102
Host walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
Host walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
euca-prod-1-82:s3cmd haroldspencerjr$ host eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com has address 192.168.39.101
Host eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
Host eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com not found: 3(NXDOMAIN)
euca-prod-1-82:s3cmd haroldspencerjr$ nslookup walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
Address: 192.168.39.102

euca-prod-1-82:s3cmd haroldspencerjr$ nslookup eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
Server:		10.1.1.254
Address:	10.1.1.254#53

Non-authoritative answer:
Name:	eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
Address: 192.168.39.101
euca-prod-1-82:s3cmd haroldspencerjr$ dig walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com

; <<>> DiG 9.8.3-P1 <<>> walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 30600
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
walrus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. 20 IN A 192.168.39.102

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. 604691 IN NS	viking-01.

;; Query time: 186 msec
;; SERVER: 10.1.1.254#53(10.1.1.254)
;; WHEN: Mon Mar 11 15:49:55 2013
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 96

euca-prod-1-82:s3cmd haroldspencerjr$ dig eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com

; <<>> DiG 9.8.3-P1 <<>> eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 31251
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 1, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. IN	A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
eucalyptus.euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. 20	IN A 192.168.39.101

;; AUTHORITY SECTION:
euca-hasp.eucalyptus-systems.com. 604678 IN NS	viking-01.

;; Query time: 207 msec
;; SERVER: 10.1.1.254#53(10.1.1.254)
;; WHEN: Mon Mar 11 15:50:08 2013
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 100
{code}

Example of DNS falling "asleep".  I was able to list Walrus buckets using s3cmd.  Next attempt a minute later, and I couldn't get a resolution.

*Working request - 2013-03-11 15:39:05*

{code}

After witnessing this, I took the s3cmd tool (which works now if you use IP address as seen in EUCA-5329) and used the IP address of the ENABLED Walrus machine, and everything worked fine.  So, from a end-user point of view, Eucalyptus DNS appears to go to sleep.  Logs from both CLC/Walrus machines attached.
Logs, configs, etc. from each CLC/Walrus machine.
[~tjcramer] do we know if this was resolved by the various DNS changes in 3.3.0?
[~graziano], unsure as this wasn't specifically targeted.
